Fixes issue #838. This patch makes it possible to use loadDiv both with pushState routers and with internal AF router. loadDiv will now only remove parameters (delimited in AF by a slash) only when those parameters come after a hash character.

Update af.ui.js

Fix related with issue #837.

On first load of an Ajax Call, the href of the footer button will be = to the variable "hash" but without any hash character (#) at the beginning. Thus, the panel will correctly load with the results of an Ajax Call but the "pressed" class won't be added. The code tries to find an href having a # at the beginning (which is not the case on Ajax calls).

Last fix almost cleared all issues regarding footer buttons not being shown as pressed. Except for one case. If your app starts somewhere such as app.com/A then the footer button for "A" won't be shown as pressed in the first instance. Further clicks will work OK.

This fixes the issues for all cases.

Make sure an active class is always set

Try to add the active class again (even though in most cases the class will already be set).
This solves an issue when swapping panels A->B->A by QUICKLY tapping footer buttons on slow devices.
Under these circumstances the timeout sometimes comes after the active classes to panels A and B have been set.
You may end up having no active panels (blank page).

Patch $.ui.addContentDiv()

Allow `$.ui.addContentDiv()` to accept a pre-created DOM node as the first argument. `el` may be a DOM id with or without the leading `#`, an element wrapped by $, or a naked element.

Support for FormData submit in XHR requests

Added "processData" flag to ajaxSettings object which if set to false, will disable any $.param() processing on XHR data object.

Allow the user to set the XHR contentType value to false enabling the browser to automatically determine its value.

setting contentType to false and processData to false will enable the user to submit FormData objects via XHR requests which is helpful when submitting large content data or file inputs via XHR requests.

$('body').append() will never execute script. **Note: this might not be a bug, if you think it is a good idea to execute script in $(selector).append() just as jQuery does.** ### bug decription the script which is appended to the DOM will never be executed. ### how to reproduce? try this ``` af('body').append(''); af('body').append('
this is newly added.
'); ``` ### how to fix? the code below never get a chance to run. ``` if (obj.nodeName != nundefined && obj.nodeName.toLowerCase() == "script" && (!obj.type || obj.type.toLowerCase() === 'text/javascript')) { window['eval'](obj.innerHTML); } ``` **because the obj is either a $afm instance or undefined, so the obj.nodeName will always be undefined.** so I just changed the code logic to make it works, check it out. a little more advice: if you do think it is really not a good idea to support this feature due to the performance of af, then just discard it.

According to the docs, instance method `.delegate`'s argument `data` is optional, but the truth is `data` is required. this PR just fixed it.
And some slight modification for `for` loop execution efficiency.

$('body').append() will never execute script. **Note: this might not be a bug, if you think it is a good idea to execute script in $(selector).append() just as jQuery does.** ### bug decription the script which is appended to the DOM will never be executed. ### how to reproduce? try this ``` af('body').append(''); af('body').append('
this is newly added.
'); ``` ### how to fix? the code below never get a chance to run. ``` if (obj.nodeName != nundefined && obj.nodeName.toLowerCase() == "script" && (!obj.type || obj.type.toLowerCase() === 'text/javascript')) { window['eval'](obj.innerHTML); } ``` **because the obj is either a $afm instance or undefined, so the obj.nodeName will always be undefined.** so I just changed the code logic to make it works, check it out. a little more advice: if you do think it is really not a good idea to support this feature due to the performance of af, then just discard it.

fix a bug for browsers which are not based on webkit rendering engine.

### bug discription
the `header.innerHTML` should be changed to `this.header.innerHTML` in line 1683, it will throw an error which **header is not defined** if you are not on Webkit, because the variable `header` hasn't be defined at all, the Webkit provides a shortcut for `document.getElementById(someId)`, that is `someId`, so, you're accidently correct on Webkit, if not, the code will break.

### how to reproduce?
test on any platforms rather that Webkit.

### how to fix?
changed `header.innerHTML` to `this.header.innerHTML` in line 1683.
apply mask only if no fixed sidemenu

changed the returned value of width()/height() back to a number.

**Note: this may not a bug, but I think there is a better solution to handle the unity thing.**
### solution decription
there was [a older commit](https://github.com/01org/appframework/commit/a94fdadcb39e64dd7e5d4164384ad4e36bf2bdc5) from kyo-ago, I did not figure out why such a change has been made, after modification, the users who are familiar with jQuery will be strongly confused, and didn't see any benefit from that change.
Here is the [issue](https://github.com/01org/appframework/issues/483).

### how to do it better?
just convert the variable `tmpVal` from string to number via `+tmpVal`, so only number will be returned from `width()/height()` now, everybody's happy.

fix a typo, change `offsetheight/offsetwidth` to `offsetHeight/offsetWidth`

you will always get `undefined` via af(document).width()/af(document).height() in the meantime.

fixed sticky slidemenu

removed doMenu = false in "if (Math.abs(dy - startY) > Math.abs(dx - startX))" -> this was leaving the panel stuck in between, without this it will snap to either open or close. 

removed "if (dx > max) return true;" -> this was only allowing panel swipe starting within the first 256px (width of sidemenu).

if (dx-startX > max) return true; -> will make sure that panel will not slide out more that the width of side menu

if (startX-dx > max) return true; -> will make sure that panel will not slide in more that the width of side menu

Add test for $.jsonP with success property

This tests that an anonymous callback is provided in the
querystring in a jsonp request, where the success callback
is passed to $.jsonP().
Modify $.jsonP() test to use server

Switch to an express server for testing $.ajax()

The previous approach (using a hacked xmlhttprequest plus
custom http implementation) worked for $.ajax(). However, it failed
for some $.jsonP() requests, where we expect the server to
use querystring variables to tailor the returned script file
to the request (i.e. wrap the returned JSON in the callback
specified in the querystring).

By using a custom express server instead, we can still support
the same set of $.ajax() tests, but can also do full $.jsonP()
testing.

Note that this opens a random, unallocated, high-numbered port
on the host running the tests for the server. The server should
be closed after running the tests.

Also note that we still have to use node-xmlhttprequest, as
jsdom's XMLHttpRequest doesn't support POST. In addition, we
also modify node-xmlhttprequest so that it can return XML
(the original doesn't set responseXML, which is used by
appframework).

Add simple test for jsonp()

This tests the case where the jsonp request is made with
a callback name hard-coded into the returned script file.

The other use case for jsonp is where the script is requested
with a querystring like "http://host/script?callback=mycallback".
The server then returns a script with the callback name
from the querystring embedded, e.g. "mycallback({a: 1, b: 2});".

As this requires processing on the server-side (to extract
the querystring variable and customise the content of the
returned script file), there's no test for this case yet.

Add tests for $.ajax()

This uses a modified version of node-xmlhttprequest plus a faked
node.js http module implementation to enable fake XMLHttpRequests
to be intercepted and tested.

One shortcoming at the moment is that it doesn't test the
data written during the request, only the headers sent.
Add tests for closest()
Add tests for prop()

Expose chai's expect() function globally

This enables more natural syntax for test cases where

Add tests to cover modifications to $.getCssMatrix()

$.getCssMatrix() should always return a matrix

If no element is supplied to $.getCssMatrix(), and either of
window.WebKitCSSMatrix or window.MSCSSMatrix are set, the
function returns a function rather than a matrix.

To ensure consistency and no surprises, change the method so
that it always returns a matrix object (fake or real).

In addition, previously, if there is no transform property available
in the computed style object, an exception would be thrown,
and caught to return a default matrix. Rather than using
exceptions to control flow, check for the existence of a transform
string before attempting to process it. If not available,
default to returning an "empty" matrix.

Fix removeClass tests to work with jsdom

In domino, $(selector).attr('attr') returns undefined if
an attribute is not defined. In jsdom, the same method call
returns null (which matches the browser more closely).

Fix the tests so they pass with jsdom.

Use jsdom rather than domino

domino doesn't support the full DOM API; in particular,
the "elements" property on form elements is missing.

jsdom does a better job of supporting the full DOM API, but
requires an older version of node than I was using. So I changed
the node engine requirements in package.json and .travis.yml
to ensure that tests are run with the correct node version.
